quick_start.title: What HTML Actually Does
quick_start.description:
When you write HTML, you‚Äôre not just ‚Äúputting letters on the web.‚Äù
You‚Äôre describing the structure and meaning of everything that appears on a webpage.

Think of a webpage like a human body:
	‚Ä¢	HTML is the skeleton ‚Üí it gives shape (head, arms, legs).
	‚Ä¢	CSS is the clothing and style ‚Üí it makes it look nice.
	‚Ä¢	JavaScript is the muscle and brain ‚Üí it makes things move and react.

So yes ‚Äî HTML is what tells the browser what should appear (text, images, links, forms‚Ä¶),
but even more, it tells the browser what each thing is (a title, a paragraph, a list, etc.).

This is my first paragraph on the web.

quick_start.title: What Is That At The Top Of Every HTML Code?
quick_start.description:
You‚Äôre talking about the first line that always goes at the very top of every HTML file.
That‚Äôs called the DOCTYPE declaration.

Let‚Äôs break it down so you truly understand it.
üí° What it means:

This line tells the browser:

‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm an HTML5 document ‚Äî please read and render me using modern HTML rules.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not actually an HTML tag (like <html> or <body>).
It‚Äôs an instruction to the browser ‚Äî a kind of agreement between you and the browser about how your page should be interpreted.

üß† Think of it like this:

If your webpage were a movie script:
	‚Ä¢	<!DOCTYPE html> = ‚ÄúThis script follows modern movie rules ‚Äî not the old black-and-white ones.‚Äù

quick_start.title: What Is The Ideal Top For Any HTML Code?
quick_start.description:
Let‚Äôs build the perfect, professional, industry-standard HTML5 skeleton, just like a developer with 30+ years of experience would write it ‚Äî clean, structured, documented, and standards-compliant.
üß† Why This Looks Professional
	‚Ä¢	Every line has purpose (no junk, no repetition).
	‚Ä¢	Comments show that the developer documents their work ‚Äî this is key in senior-level codebases.
	‚Ä¢	Meta tags cover:
	‚Ä¢	Encoding (UTF-8)
	‚Ä¢	Responsiveness (viewport)
	‚Ä¢	SEO & sharing (description, og:)
	‚Ä¢	Structure is perfectly semantic:
	‚Ä¢	<header> for intro/nav
	‚Ä¢	<main> for core content
	‚Ä¢	<footer> for copyright or links
	‚Ä¢	Readable indentation ‚Äî clean and consistent.
quick_start.code:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <!-- ‚úÖ Character encoding: ensures correct display of all characters -->
    <meta charset="UTF-8" />

    <!-- ‚úÖ Viewport: makes the page responsive on all devices -->
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />

    <!-- ‚úÖ SEO: short, clear description for search engines -->
    <meta name="description" content="A clean, modern HTML5 base template for professional web projects." />

    <!-- ‚úÖ Author (optional but good practice for professional portfolios) -->
    <meta name="author" content="Luis Eduardo Casta√±eda Ruiz" />

    <!-- ‚úÖ Social media preview (Open Graph & Twitter Cards, optional but modern) -->
    <meta property="og:title" content="Professional HTML5 Template" />
    <meta property="og:description" content="A fully structured HTML5 document built with best practices." />
    <meta property="og:type" content="website" />
    <meta property="og:image" content="https://example.com/preview.png" />
    <meta property="og:url" content="https://example.com/" />
    <meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image" />

    <!-- ‚úÖ Favicon (small icon that appears in the browser tab) -->
    <link rel="icon" href="favicon.ico" type="image/x-icon" />

    <!-- ‚úÖ External CSS file (we‚Äôll add one later when styling) -->
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" />

    <!-- ‚úÖ Document title -->
    <title>Professional HTML5 Template</title>
  </head>
</html>

quick_start.title: What Are Attributes?
quick_start.description:
Every HTML tag can have attributes.
They are extra pieces of information that modify or describe how the tag behaves.

builtins.description:
is an HTML tag ‚Äî specifically, it‚Äôs the root tag (or ‚Äúparent‚Äù of everything). It‚Äôs what wraps all the content of your webpage. Every tag you write (, ,

,

, etc.) must live inside ... . üß© A few facts: ‚Ä¢ It‚Äôs a built-in HTML element ‚Äî part of the HTML standard. ‚Ä¢ You can add attributes to it, like the page language:

builtins.name: <meta>
builtins.description:
The <meta> tag goes inside the <head> section of your HTML document.
It provides metadata ‚Äî information about the page rather than what appears on the page.
üß† What It‚Äôs Used For
	1.	Encoding (very important!)
This tells the browser which character set to use ‚Äî basically how to read all letters, symbols, and emojis correctly.
	2.	SEO (Search Engine Optimization)
	‚Ä¢	Helps search engines understand your page content.
	3.	Author or Viewport Info
	‚Ä¢	The viewport tag helps your site look good on mobile screens:

builtins.name: lang
builtins.description:
Used in: <html> tag

Meaning:
Tells the browser and search engines what language the document is in.

Use case:
Always include it for accessibility and SEO.
"en" for English, "es" for Spanish, "fr" for French, etc.

builtins.name: charset
builtins.description:
Used in: <meta>

Meaning:
Defines the character encoding ‚Äî how letters, symbols, and emojis are represented.

Use case:
Always set it to "UTF-8" ‚Äî it supports nearly all characters and languages.

builtins.name: name
builtins.description:
Used in: <meta>, <input>, <form>, etc.

Meaning:
Labels what kind of metadata is being given.
In forms, it identifies the input field when data is sent.

Use case:
	‚Ä¢	For metadata (in <head>)
	‚Ä¢	For identifying input fields in forms

builtins.name: content
builtins.description:
Used in: <meta>

Meaning:
The actual value of the metadata you‚Äôre describing.
It works together with the name attribute.

Use case:
Any time you‚Äôre defining a <meta> tag.

builtins.name: initial-scale
builtins.description:
Used in: inside the content of the viewport meta tag.

Meaning:
Tells the browser the default zoom level when the page loads on mobile.
1.0 means ‚Äúdon‚Äôt zoom in or out.‚Äù

Use case:
Always include this in responsive designs.

builtins.name: property
builtins.description:
Used in: <meta> (especially for Open Graph, social media sharing)

Meaning:
Defines a specific property for platforms like Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.
It‚Äôs part of the Open Graph protocol.

Use case:
Any time you want your page to show a nice preview when shared.

builtins.name: rel
builtins.description:
Used in: <link> and <a>

Meaning:
Describes the relationship between the current page and the linked file.

Use case:
	‚Ä¢	rel="stylesheet" ‚Üí link to CSS
	‚Ä¢	rel="icon" ‚Üí link to favicon
	‚Ä¢	rel="noopener" ‚Üí security for external links

builtins.name: href
builtins.description:
Used in: <a> and <link>

Meaning:
Specifies the URL (link or file location).

Use case:
Whenever you want to link to another file or website.

builtins.name: type
builtins.description:
Used in: <link>, <script>, <button>, <input>

Meaning:
Describes the type of file or content.

Use case:
	‚Ä¢	For linking icons or scripts (type="image/x-icon", type="text/javascript")
	‚Ä¢	For buttons/inputs (type="submit", type="text", etc.)

builtins.name: <h1>, <h2>, <h3>, <h4>, <h5>, <h6>
builtins.description:
These are called heading tags. They show hierarchy, just like chapter titles and subtitles in a book. the numbers (1-6) indicate the level of importance, with <h1> being the most important and <h6> the least.

üß† Why Use Them?
	‚Ä¢	SEO: Search engines use headings to understand the structure and main topics of your content.
	‚Ä¢	Accessibility: Screen readers use headings to help users navigate your page.
	‚Ä¢	Organization: They break up content into sections, making it easier to read.
